Salesman: Hello, I'd like to interest you in committing to a donation towards the Save the Children fund, an international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries. Customer: I appreciate your concern. Customer: Tell me more about this charity before I make a decision. Salesman: Save the Children is a foundation that runs world-wide with a focus on providing health, education, protection, hunger elimination, emergency aid, and global advocacy. Salesman: So far we have reached 155 million children in 120 countries. Customer: Interesting that you know so much. Customer: How long has this charity been around? Salesman: The charity was founded in 1919 and their belief is that every child deserves a future so nearly 90% of every dollar goes directly into the mission itself while the remaining 10% goes directly into fundraising and advocacy awareness programs to help promote their current efforts. Customer: That is important that most of the money goes to the charity and not into administration. Salesman: Agreed, they post their yearly audit reports so that individuals can track where the funds are allocated. Customer: It looks like they will be celebrating their 100 year anniversary soon. Customer: That is quite a milestone. Salesman: Yes, they are an extremely reputable charity that have been in good standing for the entirety of their history. Salesman: Originally founded immediately after World War I when so many children were orphaned and/or homeless. Customer: That is interesting. Customer: Do they do work in the United States or just overseas? Salesman: They work world wide providing both support in the US and overseas, the US chapter was founded in 1932 following the great depression, and today their team goes where other's cannot - to the most rural communities in the US. Salesman: Last year, they provided support to 237,000 US children across 22 states and Puerto Rico. Customer: What country outside of the US do they do the most help for? Salesman: Other than the US, Africa receives 43% of the budget, helping more than 32 million children in 2016 across Burkina Faso, Burundi, Democratic Republic of Congo, Ethiopia, Guinea, Kenya, Liberia, Malawi, Mali, Mozambique, Niger, Nigeria, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. Salesman: How do you feel about childrens charities? Salesman: Do you feel like they do good work and are important to society? Customer: I believe that childrens charity is very much needed in society. Customer: We see children going through difficult times including things like cancer and several other illnesses that are life-threatening. Customer: I do have a soft spot for children. Customer: I think it's crucial to tell whether these charities are in fact going towards children in need. Customer: Parents who don't have the necessary financial support to provide their children with the care they need. Salesman: I totally agree - I have a young child and when I see images of children starving or suffering it really makes me want to help out however I can. Salesman: I can't imagine living in a place where I had to worry about my child dying from hunger or human rights abuses. Salesman: I think the work that charities can do is so important. Salesman: Especially when it is a legitimate charity that is dedicated to doing better. Salesman: Have you heard about the charity Save the children? Customer: yes I have. Customer: In fact, I've recently did some research on this charity and found so many community events that help children in general. Customer: Whether it'd be for back-to-school supplies or changing the lives of bright children. Customer: One of the things that really touch my heart is preventing malnutrition. Customer: Millions of children die each year due to poor health and so having a nutrition program, ensure's that children will grow up healthy. Salesman: It is always shocking to me how far charities can make money go to help enrich the lives of children. Salesman: You would not think that something as simple as skipping a cup of morning coffee to donate to a charity would be able to make such a huge impact in the life of a child, but it really does. Salesman: I think that if more people realized how giving up a little in our lives could save the life of a child that more people would participate in charity. Do you think that is true? Customer: I believe it could be true. Customer: However, I think a lot of people would question whether these charities are legitimate. Customer: One thing that people would look upon is proof of legitimacy. Customer: If they can see for themselves and or participate in some kind of a charity event, then they would want to contribute to this. Salesman: I agree. Salesman: It is so important to do your research when deciding to support a charity. Salesman: It is sad that there are charities that pop up that end up using more of the funds for their own needs rather than a legitimate one like Save the children that has verifiable credentials and obvious international impact. Salesman: Do you think charities should be more transparent about how they will be using the funds? Customer: Personally, transparency is especially vital. Customer: When you become so passionate about something like this, you would want the world to become more involved in this passion of yours. Customer: In turn, they would have an idea of the tribulations that others go through, as well as, becoming more sympathetic towards society in general. Customer: If you have nothing to hide then this would not be a problem. Salesman: I agree. Salesman: I prefer to know that the donation I am making big or small is actually going to be going to a trustable fund. Salesman: Do you think that people who have the ability to help have a moral obligation to do so? Customer: Honestly, it should be a choice. Customer: I don't think of it as a moral obligation, necessarily. Customer: However, I think people should open their eyes to things like this because if they really look at the big picture and find that it could possibly affect their lives in the future then they should be more involved and play a role in helping others. Salesman: I think looking at the big picture is a good way to see it. Salesman: I believe that most people would make a choice to help with what they could without any sense of guilt or obligation. Salesman: I think most people would help just to help. Salesman: Do you think people are fundamentally eager to help with what they can like that? Customer: I think so. Customer: Depending on their financial standpoint, I think people would contribute to a charity like this if they have the funds to do so. Customer: If they don't, it's completely understandable. Customer: In many places, living expenses are very expensive so they may or may not be able to. Customer: However, every cent counts. Customer: It wouldn't matter how big or how small the donation is. Customer: It's all about giving. Salesman: I think that would be a more effective message sometimes. Salesman: Some people may think that they need to be wealthy in order to contribute, that their $5 donation could not possibly do anything to help. Salesman: Do you think people would be more likely to donate if they say the impact very small donations could have? Salesman: Or do you think that people would feel like microdonations would not be effective no matter what? Customer: Those are very good questions. Customer: It depends on the way they see it. Customer: Those who believe in the gift of giving and are generous regardless of the price then a small donation could count as much as a $100 donation could. Customer: Nonetheless, if your views are small and you only look at these donations at a high price, then small donations wouldn't count for anything. Customer: Overall, I feel any donation is acceptable and could count towards a good meal for a child. Salesman: Hello, have you heard of Save The Children? Customer: I think so, it sounds familiar. Customer: it is a nonprofit charity if i recall. Customer: What exactly do they do? Customer: How long has Save the Children been around? Salesman: It was founded in 1919, on April 15th in London - UK.
